In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In September 2010, representatives from 11 ministries of education of Pacific countries 
met in Papua New Guinea and agreed to support a new learning assessment tool for use in 
early primary education grades. The early grade learning assessment (EGLA), which includes 
both early grade literacy assessment (EGRA) and early grade numeracy assessment, has been 
decided upon as the preferred assessment tool. Education secretaries’ meetings in 2011 further 
discussed the strategy on EGRA application in the Pacific region and agreed to roll out EGRA in 
the  region,  utilizing  the  Tonga  model  as  a  successful  example.  The  Federated  States  of 
Micronesia (FSM), the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI), and Palau requested that the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  support  the  implementation  of  EGLA  in  their  respective 
countries. This initiative will be the first project in Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) 
to  have  both  EGRA  and  early  grade  numeracy  assessment  aspects.  While  the  regional 
technical assistance (TA) was not included in the Pacific regional operations business plan 
(2010–2013),1 in  response  to the  countries' requests, the TA  concept  was  developed  and 
approved by the ADB vice-president (Operations 2) on 8 August 2011. The TA will contribute to 
improved quality of primary school education, and EGLA outcomes in the three participating 
countries  will  contribute  to  further  comparative  analyses  in  the  region.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Access to education and outcomes in the Pacific. Over the past 10 years, the United 
Nations’ Education for All3 campaign and the Millennium Development Goals have focused their 
attention on educational achievements. This attention has led to measurable success; Pacific 
DMCs have made significant progress towards universal access to primary education, with 
average enrollment rates of more than 80%.4 However, in almost all Pacific DMCs student 
learning outcomes still lag significantly behind improvements in access to schooling.5 Evidence 
from most Pacific DMCs6 that participate in international assessments, such as the Programme 
for  International  Student  Assessment  (PISA),7 indicates  that  Pacific  students  are  greatly 
underrepresented  in  the  high-achieving  groups  in  literacy  and  mathematics  assessments.8 
Nearly one-third of students in Pacific DMCs  were at the lowest proficiency level in the PISA 
measures in 2007, compared with only 9% of European students were at that level. Similarly, for 
mathematics, nearly one-third of students in Pacific DMCs performed at the lowest levels in the 
PISA assessment (footnote 7).  
 
3.  Challenges  in  measuring  learning  outcomes.  Difficulties  with  learning  in  many 
schools often begin during the first year of schooling. Failure of children to acquire basic skills in

2   
literacy and numeracy in the early grades leads to increased grade repetition and dropouts, and 
ultimately reduced opportunities and lower social skills. Yet, few developing countries, including 
Pacific  DMCs,  give  priority  to  measuring  how  well  children  are  acquiring  reading  and 
mathematics skills in the early grades.9 Many countries develop national assessments in an 
attempt to measure learning outcomes against nationally defined standards,10 but nearly all 
national and international assessments are paper-and-pencil tests administered to students in 
grade 3 and above. In the RMI, the Ministry of Education (MOE) began using the Marshall 
Islands Standardized Achievement Test. However, this test is only intended to measure the 
learning outcomes against students above grade 3. Because these tests assume that students 
can read and write, it is not always possible to distinguish between students who score poorly 
because they lack the knowledge tested by the assessments or because they lack basic reading 
and comprehension skills.11   
 
4.  Progress in student performance assessment systems in the Pacific. Countries in 
the Pacific region have made some advances in terms of systematic assessment of student 
performance, although more progress is needed. Most Pacific DMCs have conducted at least 
one national student assessment since 2000, but the scientific reliability and validity of these 
assessments reportedly varies greatly (footnote 8). The MOE in most Pacific DMCs lacks the 
experience  and  expertise  to  carry  out  rigorous  assessments  of  learning  outcomes.  In 
September 2010, during the meeting of education ministers, it was agreed that a new learning 
assessment tool  for  early  grades  in  primary  education  would  be  supported.  Three  Pacific 
countries have already begun implementing EGRA in partnership with the World Bank, while 
several others considered starting pilot EGLA in 2011. EGLA is a simplified assessment tool 
that could report on the foundation levels of student learning, including an assessment of the 
first steps students take in learning to read, recognizing letters of the alphabet, reading simple 
words, and understanding simple mathematics.  
 
5.  In Tonga, EGRA is included as part of the primary school curriculum, and learning 
materials and teaching strategies are tailored according to each student’s learning achievement. 
Based on the successful outcomes of the Tongan EGRA, many Pacific DMCs have expressed 
interest in replicating EGLA in their countries.     
 
6.  The TA will support the FSM, Palau, and the RMI to initiate EGLA at grades 2 and 5 of 
selected primary schools. The objective is to help the participating countries begin the process 
of systematically measuring how well children in the early grades of primary are acquiring 
reading  and  mathematics  skills,  and  ultimately  spur  more  effective  efforts  to  improve 
performance in these core learning areas. The TA will use Tonga's integrated approach to pilot 
EGLA in the FSM, Palau, and the RMI.  
 
7.  To strengthen the link between learning assessment and learning methods, the TA will 
also support improved teaching techniques and learning approaches in reading and numeracy, 
adopting  a  methodology  of  individualized  learning  and  assessment  based  on  repetition, 
accuracy, and speed.12 The key to individualized instruction is to study at the “just right” level. 
The starting point for each student will be determined individually in coordination with EGLA.

8.  Every student has diverse learning curves and different learning styles. In addition, 
students acquire new knowledge at different rates and also come from different socio-economic 
backgrounds.  One  standardized  education  program  will  therefore  not  work  equally  for  all 
students. The individualized learning approach provides students the opportunity to learn at 
their own pace through a custom made program that meets their special learning curves and 
allows  them  to  reach their greatest  potential.  This  approach  has  a  proven  track-record to 
improve the overall leaning outcomes of education in many countries.13 
  
9.  The TA will be funded by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR). ADB will work 
closely  with  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (JICA)  volunteers  who already  have 
significant experience in managing various education projects in the three target countries as a 
result of their role as school teachers in the three countries. The TA’s objective of improved 
access to quality education is in line with the priority areas identified in ADB’s Strategy 202014 
and ADB’s education operations plan.15 To the extent possible, the EGLA core strategy will be 
aligned with other development partners16 who are supporting EGLA elsewhere in the region. 
This  will  promote further  regional  consistency  and  efforts  to  monitor  learning  outcomes  in 
primary education.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact will be improved access to quality education for primary school students in 
FSM, Palau, and RMI. The outcome will be that participating governments integrate EGLA in 
nine  schools  for  grades  2  and  5  and  develop  individualized  learning  and  assessment 
approaches.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will achieve the following four outputs with key activities: 
 
12.  Output 1: Pilot early grade learning assessment in nine schools. The TA will assist 
FSM,17 Palau, and RMI to pilot EGLA at grades 2 and 5 in three primary schools in each country. 
Under the TA, EGLA materials will be developed; training for trainers will be provided; and 
workshops to introduce EGLA to MOEs, communities, and schools will be conducted. EGLA 
baseline survey and data analysis will be supported. Community participation will be promoted 
through regular EGLA school meetings with communities.  
 
13.  Output 2: Develop individualized learning approaches. The TA will support each of 
three participating countries to develop an individualized learning approach to literacy and 
                                                                                                                                                       
next level only when they have mastered the previous level. These approaches have been successfully trialed 
in more  than  46  countries.  Individualized  learning  and  assessment  methodology  providers  have  existing 
operations in the Pacific region through their operation centers in Australia and New Zealand.

numeracy. Learning methods and teaching materials will be procured and a special learning 
center  established  in  each  country  during  the  TA  period  to  apply  and  administer  the 
individualized learning approach. Training for learning center staff will be provided on monitoring 
EGLA outcomes and administering the individualized learning approach.  
 
14.  Output  3:  Integrate  early  grade  learning  assessment  with  the  education 
management  information  system.  Under  the  TA,  the  quality  of  the  existing  education 
management information system (EMIS) will be assessed and a feasibility analysis for the 
integration of EGLA with the EMIS carried out. EMIS training for trainers, school teachers, and 
MOEs will be provided to improve the EMIS quality with EGLA data. To improve the EMIS, 
necessary information and communication technology equipment will be procured under the TA. 
 
15.  Output  4:  Early  grade  learning  assessment  data  regional  comparison  and 
replication nationwide. The TA will assist participating governments to develop a publication 
on  EGLA,  and  the  Asia  South  Pacific  Board  for  Education  Assessment  to  conduct  a 
comparative impact analyses on the EGLA pilot within the countries18 and with other regions. A 
regional workshop will be organized to disseminate the EGLA outcome. The documentation and 
workshop will recommend approaches to  scale up EGLA nationwide in the three selected 
countries if the results of the impact evaluations are satisfactory.  
 
16.  Major assumptions and risks. Major assumptions of the TA are that the governments 
of the three countries are committed to improving the quality of primary education, and fully 
understand  the  added  value  of  EGLA  and  individualized  learning  approaches.  It  is  also 
assumed that the implementing units of the MOEs are able to release staff and enumerators 
and/or supervisors during the TA implementation, in particular during the baseline survey. In 
addition, it is assumed that the capacity of schools is considered to be adequate to use EGLA 
on a regular basis, and target schools will work closely with special learning centers introduced 
by the TA to establish good links between learning assessment and development of materials. 
 
17.  Potential  risks  for  the  TA  are  that  there  will  be  a  high  turnover  of  teachers  from 
designated schools, or development partners may introduce a new learning assessment tool 
without coordination with EGLA. JICA volunteers will work closely with the schools to ensure the 
integration of EGLA, and ADB together with JICA volunteers will ensure the introduction of new 
tools is coordinated among development partners. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $1,650,000 equivalent. The governments of FSM, 
Palau, and RMI have requested ADB to finance $1,350,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by the JFPR, and administered by ADB. The three participating governments 
will provide in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency  of  the  TA,  responsible  for  all  recruitment  of 
consultants and procurement in consultation with the host governments. The MOEs of the FSM, 
Palau, and the RMI will be the implementing agencies. Each MOE will identify a responsible 
officer  for  coordination  of  the  outputs  with  consultants.  Training  and  workshops  will  be 
implemented and administered by the consultants. Implementing units of the MOEs will work

with existing volunteers from the JICA at primary schools to coordinate and monitor outputs 1–3 
in each country. 
 
20.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will require 
a total of 66 person-months of consultant services (42 person-months of international and 24 
person-months of national) as follows: (i) team leader, 12 person-months, (ii) EGLA experts in 
literacy  and  numeracy,  10  person-months;  (iii)  education  data  management  experts,                    
10 person-months; (iv) education quality specialist, 10 person-months; (v) education statistics 
and data management specialist, 6 person-months; and (vi) pool of consultants, 18 person-
months. The consultants will be engaged individually by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement will follow ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Some of the consultants will 
work on an intermittent basis or will be recruited later, responding to government requirements 
and progress made during implementation. The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from       
1 May 2012 to 30 April 2014. Outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,350,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Quality Primary Education in the 
North Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 42 person-months of international consultant 
services and 24 person-months of national consultant services. The consultants will be engaged 
individually in accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Some of the consultants will work on an 
intermittent basis or will be recruited later, responding to the governments' requirements, and so 
a flexible approach will be required. The TA will be implemented over 24 months from when the 
consultants are first fielded. The TA team will deliver the outcomes and outputs of the TA as 
indicated in the TA report. The TA team will help ADB and the governments with any other 
assignments in addition to the terms of reference, as may be reasonably expected within their 
scope of work. 
 
2.  The  TA  is  expected  to  assist  the  governments  and  other  key  stakeholders  in  the 
development of an implementation strategy for the early grade learning assessment (EGLA) and 
individualized learning and assessment approaches in reading and numeracy, including a plan 
with indicative timeline and scope of work. The TA will support the governments in completing 
an analysis that will form the basis of this strategy.  
 
3.  The following deliverables and activities are planned: 
(i)  inception report;  
(ii)  first draft report, based on document analysis, field visits, and interviews with 
major stakeholders, to include 
(a) design and implementation of EGLA baseline survey; 
(b) institutional  implications  and  options  for  institutional 
arrangements for EGLA implementation; 
(c) implementation strategy, including plan, targets, and time frame; 
(d) options for the sequencing of EGLA and individualized learning and 
assessment approaches in reading and numeracy implementation; 
(e) necessary capacity development activities for Ministry of Education 
(MOE)  staff,  school  teachers,  and  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency volunteers; 
(f)  proposed  methods  on  how  EGLA  can  be  best  integrated  with 
individualized  learning  and  assessment  approaches  in  reading  and 
numeracy; 
(g) implications  for  monitoring  and  measuring  improved  learning 
achievements and collection of accurate data; and 
(h) options for the introduction of a possible sector-wide approach; 
(iii)  quarterly progress reports (format to be agreed); and 
(iv)  final report (format to be agreed). 
 
B.  International and National Experts 
 
1.   Team Leader (international, 12 person-months) 
 
4.  The team leader will work closely with the host governments and ADB and provide in-
depth experience and knowledge of the political economy in the countries and in the education 
sector in particular. During the analysis phase, the team leader will (i) assist in the institutional 
analysis and arrangements, and in the analysis of the most viable options for introducing the

EGLA  and  individualized  learning  and  assessment  approaches  in  reading  and  numeracy;             
(ii) provide a view on political and economy of countries to assess the feasibility of the EGLA; 
and (iii) help to ensure the involvement of all the key stakeholders during the TA, especially 
during development of and discussion on the implementation strategy. 
 
5.  During the development of the implementation strategy, the team leader, together with 
his/her team members, will (i) ensure the proper design of the consultation and decision making 
process within the MOEs, with other government agencies, and with all other key stakeholders; 
(ii) ensure the quality of the focus group discussions, required capacity development, based on 
extensive knowledge of the key stakeholders in the sector; (iii) guide the consultation process of 
the implementation plan; and (iv) facilitate a high-level workshop where agreement on the 
implementation strategy will be sought. To provide this support, the team leader is expected to 
have in-depth knowledge of and experience at a senior level in education assessment and 
management in the Pacific. The team leader needs to be familiar with all the stakeholders in the 
education sector and have broad experience in foreign assistance programs and projects. A 
background in education policy and management is required. 
 
6.  During the implementation of the project, the team leader will ensure that the project is 
implemented  according  to  the  agreed  implementation  strategy.  The  team  leader  will  also 
ensure that the inputs of all other consulting team members are of good quality. 
 
2.  Early  Grade  Learning  Assessment  Experts  in  Literacy  and  Numeracy 
(international, 10 person-months) 
 
7.  Two EGLA experts will be recruited to design and develop EGLA assessment tools and 
necessary materials in English. The reading expert is responsible for designing, field testing, 
and  completing  tools  and  materials  for  reading  assessment  at  grades  2  and  5.  The 
mathematics expert will be responsible for the same functions for numeracy. The two experts 
will  also  participate  in  various  training  sessions  for  MOEs,  school  teachers,  and  Japan 
International Cooperation Agency volunteers. 
 
3.  Education Data Management Experts (international, 10 person-months) 
 
8.  The  education  data  management  experts  will  be  responsible  for  analysis  of  the 
implications of the EGLA implementation on the provision of timely, accurate, and complete 
information on all the schools, teachers, and students. This analysis will focus on how the 
current data collection, storage, and usage system needs to be reformed to implement EGLA, 
and  how  EGLA  data  can  be  used  to  link  with  individualized  learning  and  assessment 
approaches in reading and numeracy. The analysis also needs to focus on the systemic level: 
what will the EGLA look like, what is the system like at the moment, and how can the EGLA be 
complementary to the current system? The education data management experts will work 
closely with the national education statistics and data management experts. The other national 
experts, the team leader, and the education quality specialist will support the education data 
management experts. The experts will also assist in the other analyses, where possible, in 
collaboration with the World Bank. To provide this support, the experts are expected to have 
knowledge  of  and  experience  in  designing,  implementing,  and  reforming  education  data 
management systems, with a particular focus on data collection, storage, and usage, preferably 
in developing countries. Experience with data processing in primary education in the Pacific is 
an asset. The specialists will also contribute to other regional efforts, e.g., the Asia South 
Pacific  Board  for  Educational  Assessment  Literacy  and  Education  Experience  Survey,  to 
complement the project for the purpose of regional comparison.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
4.  Education Quality Specialist (international, 10 person-months) 
 
9.  The education quality specialist will be responsible for (i) providing inputs on quality 
improvement of primary education with individualized learning and assessment approaches in 
reading and numeracy, based on EGLA assessment; (ii) analyzing the implications of EGLA on 
the assessment and examination system; and (iii) preparing necessary teaching and learning 
materials, as needed, in English. Being able to measure how well the system contributes to 
actual  learning  achievements  and  to  make  appropriate  improvements  is  essential  for  the 
success of the project. Where possible, the national experts, the team leader, and the EGLA 
specialists will support the education quality specialist. The specialist will also contribute to 
other regional efforts, e.g., the Asia South Pacific Board for Educational Assessment Literary 
and Education Experience Survey, to complement the project for the purpose of regional 
comparison. 
 
5.  Education Statistics and Data Management Specialist (national, 6 person-
months) 
 
10.  The  education  statistics  and  data  management  specialist  will  be  responsible  for 
providing  statistical  support  for  EGLA  data  processing  and  management  in  the  targeted 
countries. The specialist will also assist the team leader to prepare and arrange necessary 
capacity development training for stakeholders. The specialist will (i) work closely with the 
international education data management specialist in analyzing the implications of the EGLA 
for providing timely, accurate, and complete information on all targeted schools, teachers, and 
students; (ii) take the lead in the consultations supporting this analysis; and (iii) provide inputs to 
the assessment and examination system analysis. To provide this support, the specialist is 
expected to have in-depth experience in education statistics in the Pacific and education data 
collection, storage, and usage in the region, preferably having worked closely with the United 
States Compact Trust Fund. 
 
6.  Pool of Consultants (national, 18 person-months) 
 
11.   National  consultants  will  be  recruited  to  provide  local  support  to  international 
consultants during project implementation.
